pli-tv-kd18:2.1.0: 2. Discussion of the proper conduct for resident monks

pli-tv-kd18:7.1.0: 8. Discussion of the proper conduct in regard to dwellings

pli-tv-kd18:8.2.13: When leaving the sauna, he should take the sauna bench, cover himself front and back, and then leave.
pli-tv-kd18:8.2.14: If he’s able, he should also provide assistance to the senior monks in the water.

pli-tv-kd18:8.2.17: If the sauna is muddy, the last monk to leave it should clean it.
pli-tv-kd18:8.2.18: He should wash the clay trough, put away the sauna bench, extinguish the fire, close the door, and then leave.

pli-tv-kd18:10.3.1: When a monk goes to the restroom, he should stand outside and clear his throat.
pli-tv-kd18:10.3.2: Anyone sitting inside should also clear his throat.
pli-tv-kd18:10.3.3: After hanging his robe on a bamboo robe rack or a clothesline, he should enter the restroom carefully and without hurry.
pli-tv-kd18:10.3.4: He shouldn’t enter the restroom too hastily;
pli-tv-kd18:10.3.5: he shouldn’t pull up his robe before he has entered;
pli-tv-kd18:10.3.6: he should pull up his robe when he’s standing on the foot stands for defecating;
pli-tv-kd18:10.3.8: he shouldn’t clean his teeth while defecating;
pli-tv-kd18:10.3.9: he shouldn’t defecate outside the toilet;
pli-tv-kd18:10.3.10: he shouldn’t urinate outside the urinal;
pli-tv-kd18:10.3.11: he shouldn’t spit in the urinal;
pli-tv-kd18:10.3.12: he shouldn’t use coarse wiping sticks;
pli-tv-kd18:10.3.13: he shouldn’t throw the wiping sticks in the cesspit;
pli-tv-kd18:10.3.14: he should cover himself while still standing on the foot stands for defecating;
pli-tv-kd18:10.3.15: he shouldn’t leave the restroom too hastily;
pli-tv-kd18:10.3.16: he shouldn’t come out with his robe still pulled up;
pli-tv-kd18:10.3.17: he should pull up his robe when standing on the ablutions foot stands;
pli-tv-kd18:10.3.18: he shouldn’t make a chomping sound while washing;
pli-tv-kd18:10.3.19: he shouldn’t leave water in the ablutions scoop;
pli-tv-kd18:10.3.20: he should cover himself while still standing on the ablutions foot stands.
pli-tv-kd18:10.3.21: If the restroom is dirty, he should clean it.
pli-tv-kd18:10.3.22: If the wiping-stick container is full, he should discard the wiping sticks.
pli-tv-kd18:10.3.23: If the restroom is dirty, he should sweep it.
pli-tv-kd18:10.3.24: If the area surrounding the restroom is dirty, he should sweep it.
pli-tv-kd18:10.3.25: If the yard is dirty, he should sweep it.
pli-tv-kd18:10.3.26: If the gatehouse is dirty, he should sweep it.
pli-tv-kd18:10.3.27: If there’s no water in the restroom ablutions pot, he should fill it.
pli-tv-kd18:10.3.28: This is the proper conduct in regard to restrooms.”
pli-tv-kd18:11.1.0: 11. Discussion of the proper conduct toward a preceptor
pli-tv-kd18:11.1.1: At that time the students were not conducting themselves properly toward their preceptors.
pli-tv-kd18:11.1.2: The monks of few desires complained and criticized them,
pli-tv-kd18:11.1.3: “How can the students not conduct themselves properly toward their preceptors?”
pli-tv-kd18:11.1.4: They told the Buddha. Soon afterwards he had the Sangha gathered and questioned the monks:
pli-tv-kd18:11.1.5: “Is it true, monks, that the students are not conducting themselves properly toward their preceptors?”
pli-tv-kd18:11.1.11: the Buddha gave a teaching and addressed the monks:
pli-tv-kd18:11.1.12: “Well then, I’ll lay down the proper conduct for a student toward his preceptor.
pli-tv-kd18:11.2.1: A student should conduct himself properly toward his preceptor.
pli-tv-kd18:11.2.3.1: Having gotten up at the appropriate time, the student should remove his sandals and arrange his upper robe over one shoulder. He should then give his preceptor a tooth cleaner and water for rinsing the mouth, and he should prepare a seat for him.
pli-tv-kd18:11.2.4: If there’s congee, he should rinse a vessel and bring the congee to his preceptor.
pli-tv-kd18:11.2.5: When he has drunk the congee, the student should give him water and receive the vessel. Holding it low, he should wash it carefully without scratching it and then put it away.
pli-tv-kd18:11.2.6: When the preceptor has gotten up, the student should put away the seat.
pli-tv-kd18:11.2.7: If the place is dirty, he should sweep it.
pli-tv-kd18:11.3.1: If the preceptor wants to enter the village, the student should give him a sarong and receive the one he’s wearing in return. He should give him a belt. He should put the upper robes together, overlapping each other edge-to-edge, and then give them to him. He should rinse his preceptor’s bowl and give it to him while wet.
pli-tv-kd18:11.3.2: If the preceptor wants an attendant, the student should put on his sarong evenly all around, covering the navel and the knees. He should put on a belt. Putting the upper robes together, overlapping each other edge-to-edge, he should put them on and fasten the toggle. He should rinse his bowl, bring it along, and be his preceptor’s attendant.
pli-tv-kd18:11.3.3: He shouldn’t walk too far behind his preceptor or too close to him. He should receive the contents of his bowl.
pli-tv-kd18:11.4.1: He shouldn’t interrupt his preceptor when he’s speaking.
pli-tv-kd18:11.4.2: But if the preceptor’s speech is bordering on an offense, he should stop him.
pli-tv-kd18:11.4.3: When returning, the student should go first to prepare a seat and to set out a foot stool, a foot scraper, and water for washing the feet. He should go out to meet the preceptor and receive his bowl and robe. He should give him a sarong and receive the one he’s wearing in return.
pli-tv-kd18:11.4.4: If the robe is damp, he should sun it for a short while, but shouldn’t leave it in the heat.

pli-tv-kd18:11.4.8: He should place the belt in the fold.
pli-tv-kd18:11.4.9: If there’s almsfood and his preceptor wants to eat, the student should give him water and then the almsfood.
pli-tv-kd18:11.5.1: He should ask his preceptor if he wants water to drink.
pli-tv-kd18:11.5.2: When the preceptor has eaten, the student should give him water and receive his bowl. Holding it low, he should wash it carefully without scratching it. He should then dry it and sun it for a short while,
pli-tv-kd18:11.5.3: but shouldn’t leave it in the heat.
pli-tv-kd18:11.5.4: The student should put away the robe and bowl.
pli-tv-kd18:11.5.5: When putting away the bowl, he should hold the bowl in one hand, feel under the bed or the bench with the other, and then put it away.
pli-tv-kd18:11.5.6: He shouldn’t put the bowl away on the bare floor.
pli-tv-kd18:11.5.7: When putting away the robe, he should hold the robe in one hand, wipe the bamboo robe rack or the clothesline with the other, and then put it away by folding the robe over it, making the ends face the wall and the fold face out.
pli-tv-kd18:11.5.8: When the preceptor has gotten up, the student should put away the seat and also the foot stool, the foot scraper, and the water for washing the feet.
pli-tv-kd18:11.5.9: If the place is dirty, he should sweep it.”
pli-tv-kd18:11.6.1: “If the preceptor wants to bathe, the student should prepare a bath.
pli-tv-kd18:11.6.2: If he wants a cold bath, he should prepare that;
pli-tv-kd18:11.6.3: if he wants a hot bath, he should prepare that.
pli-tv-kd18:11.6.4: If the preceptor wants to take a sauna, the student should knead bath powder, moisten the clay, take a sauna bench, and follow behind his preceptor. After giving his preceptor the sauna bench, receiving his robe, and putting it aside, he should give him the bath powder and the clay.
pli-tv-kd18:11.6.5: If he’s able, he should enter the sauna.
pli-tv-kd18:11.6.6: When entering the sauna, he should smear his face with clay, cover himself front and back, and then enter.
pli-tv-kd18:11.7.1: He shouldn’t sit encroaching on the senior monks,
pli-tv-kd18:11.7.2: or block the junior monks from getting a seat.
pli-tv-kd18:11.7.3: While in the sauna, he should provide assistance to his preceptor.
pli-tv-kd18:11.7.4: When leaving the sauna, he should take the sauna bench, cover himself front and back, and then leave.
pli-tv-kd18:11.7.5: He should also provide assistance to his preceptor in the water.
pli-tv-kd18:11.7.6: When he has bathed, he should be the first to come out. He should dry himself and put on his sarong. He should then wipe the water off his preceptor’s body, and he should give him his sarong and then his upper robe. Taking the sauna bench, he should be the first to return. He should prepare a seat, and also set out a foot stool, a foot scraper, and water for washing the feet.
pli-tv-kd18:11.7.7: He should ask his preceptor if he wants water to drink.
pli-tv-kd18:11.8.1: If the preceptor wants him to recite, he should do so.
pli-tv-kd18:11.8.2: If the preceptor wants to question him, he should be questioned.”
pli-tv-kd18:11.8.3.1: “If the dwelling where the preceptor is staying is dirty, the student should clean it if he’s able.
pli-tv-kd18:11.8.4: When he’s cleaning the dwelling, he should first take out the bowl and robe and put them aside.
pli-tv-kd18:11.8.5: He should take out the sitting mat and the sheet and put them aside.

pli-tv-kd18:11.9.8: If the walls have been treated with red ocher and they’re moldy, he should moisten a cloth, wring it out, and wipe the walls.
pli-tv-kd18:11.9.9: If the floor has been treated with a black finish and it’s moldy, he should moisten a cloth, wring it out, and wipe the floor.
pli-tv-kd18:11.9.10: If the floor is untreated, he should sprinkle it with water and then sweep it,
pli-tv-kd18:11.9.11: trying to avoid stirring up dust.
pli-tv-kd18:11.9.12: He should look out for any trash and discard it.
pli-tv-kd18:11.10.1: He should sun the floor cover, clean it, beat it, bring it back inside, and put it back as before.
pli-tv-kd18:11.10.2: He should sun the bed supports, wipe them, bring them back inside, and put them back where they were.
pli-tv-kd18:11.10.3: He should sun the bed, clean it, and beat it. Holding it low, he should carefully bring it back inside without scratching it or knocking it against the door or the door frame, and he should put it back as before.
pli-tv-kd18:11.10.4: He should sun the bench, clean it, and beat it. Holding it low, he should carefully bring it back inside without scratching it or knocking it against the door or the door frame, and he should put it back as before.
pli-tv-kd18:11.10.5: He should sun the mattress and the pillow, clean them, beat them, bring them back inside, and put them back as before.
pli-tv-kd18:11.10.6: He should sun the sitting mat and the sheet, clean them, beat them, bring them back inside, and put them back as before.
pli-tv-kd18:11.10.7: He should sun the spittoon, wipe it, bring it back inside, and put it back where it was.
pli-tv-kd18:11.10.8: He should sun the leaning board, wipe it, bring it back inside, and put it back where it was.
pli-tv-kd18:11.11.1: He should put away the bowl and robe.
pli-tv-kd18:11.11.2: When putting away the bowl, he should hold the bowl in one hand, feel under the bed or the bench with the other, and then put it away.
pli-tv-kd18:11.11.3: He shouldn’t put the bowl away on the bare floor.
pli-tv-kd18:11.11.4: When putting away the robe, he should hold the robe in one hand, wipe the bamboo robe rack or the clothesline with the other, and then put it away by folding the robe over it, making the ends face the wall and the fold face out.

pli-tv-kd18:11.12.2: If dusty winds are blowing from the west, he should close the windows on the western side.
pli-tv-kd18:11.12.3: If dusty winds are blowing from the north, he should close the windows on the northern side.

pli-tv-kd18:11.14.1: “If the preceptor becomes discontent with the spiritual life, the student should send him away or have him sent away, or he should give him a teaching.
pli-tv-kd18:11.14.2: If the preceptor becomes anxious, the student should dispel it or have it dispelled, or he should give him a teaching.

pli-tv-kd18:11.15.1: If the preceptor has committed a heavy offense and deserves probation,
pli-tv-kd18:11.15.2: the student should try to get the Sangha to give it to him.
pli-tv-kd18:11.15.3: If the preceptor has committed a heavy offense and deserves to be sent back to the beginning,
pli-tv-kd18:11.15.4: the student should try to get the Sangha to do it.

pli-tv-kd18:11.15.6: the student should try to get the Sangha to give it to him.
pli-tv-kd18:11.15.7: If the preceptor has committed a heavy offense and deserves rehabilitation,
pli-tv-kd18:11.15.8: the student should try to get the Sangha to give it to him.
pli-tv-kd18:11.16.1: If the Sangha wants to do a legal procedure against his preceptor—whether a procedure of condemnation, demotion, banishment, reconciliation, or ejection—
pli-tv-kd18:11.16.2: the student should make an effort to stop it or to reduce the penalty.
pli-tv-kd18:11.16.3: But if the Sangha has already done a legal procedure against his preceptor—whether a procedure of condemnation, demotion, banishment, reconciliation, or ejection—
pli-tv-kd18:11.16.4: the student should help the preceptor conduct himself properly and suitably so as to deserve to be released, and try to get the Sangha to lift that procedure.

pli-tv-kd18:11.18.1: Without asking his preceptor for permission, he shouldn’t do any of the following: give away or receive a bowl;
pli-tv-kd18:11.18.2: give away or receive a robe;

pli-tv-kd18:11.18.5: provide assistance to anyone or have assistance provided by anyone;

pli-tv-kd18:11.18.7: be the attendant monk for anyone or take anyone as his attendant monk;

pli-tv-kd18:11.18.12: If his preceptor is sick, he should nurse him for as long as he lives or wait until he has recovered.
pli-tv-kd18:11.18.13: This is the proper conduct of a student toward his preceptor.”

pli-tv-kd18:12.11.192: When leaving the sauna, he should take the sauna bench, cover himself front and back, and then leave.
pli-tv-kd18:12.11.193: The teacher should also provide assistance to his pupil in the water.
pli-tv-kd18:12.11.194: When the teacher has bathed, he should be the first to come out. He should dry himself and put on his sarong. He should then wipe the water off his pupil’s body, and he should give him his sarong and then his upper robe. Taking the sauna bench, he should be the first to return. He should prepare a seat, and also set out a foot stool, a foot scraper, and water for washing the feet. He should ask his pupil if he wants water to drink.”
pli-tv-kd18:12.11.195.1: “If the dwelling where the pupil is staying is dirty, the teacher should clean it if he’s able.
pli-tv-kd18:12.11.196: When he’s cleaning the dwelling, he should first take out the bowl and robe and put them aside. He should take out the sitting mat and the sheet and put them aside. He should take out the mattress and the pillow and put them aside. Holding the bed low, he should carefully take it out without scratching it or knocking it against the door or the door frame, and he should put it aside. Holding the bench low, he should carefully take it out without scratching it or knocking it against the door or the door frame, and he should put it aside. He should take out the bed supports and put them aside. He should take out the spittoon and put it aside. He should take out the leaning board and put it aside. After taking note of its position, he should take out the floor cover and put it aside. If the dwelling has cobwebs, he should first remove them from the ceiling cloth, and he should then wipe the windows and the corners of the room. If the walls have been treated with red ocher and they’re moldy, he should moisten a cloth, wring it out, and wipe the walls. If the floor has been treated with a black finish and it’s moldy, he should moisten a cloth, wring it out, and wipe the floor. If the floor is untreated, he should sprinkle it with water and then sweep it, trying to avoid stirring up dust. He should look out for any trash and discard it.
pli-tv-kd18:12.11.197: He should sun the floor cover, clean it, beat it, bring it back inside, and put it back as before. He should sun the bed supports, wipe them, bring them back inside, and put them back as before. He should sun the bed, clean it, and beat it. Holding it low, he should carefully bring it back inside without scratching it or knocking it against the door or the door frame, and he should put it back as before. He should sun the bench, clean it, and beat it. Holding it low, he should carefully bring it back inside without scratching it or knocking it against the door or the door frame, and he should put it back as before. He should sun the mattress and the pillow, clean them, beat them, bring them back inside, and put them back as before. He should sun the sitting mat and the sheet, clean them, beat them, bring them back inside, and put them back as before. He should sun the spittoon, wipe it, bring it back inside, and put it back where it was. He should sun the leaning board, wipe it, bring it back inside, and put it back where it was. He should put away the bowl and robe. When putting away the bowl, he should hold the bowl in one hand, feel under the bed or the bench with the other, and then put it away. He shouldn’t put the bowl away on the bare floor. When putting away the robe, he should hold the robe in one hand, wipe the bamboo robe rack or the clothesline with the other, and then put it away by folding the robe over it, making the ends face the wall and the fold face out.
pli-tv-kd18:12.11.198: If dusty winds are blowing from the east, he should close the windows on the eastern side. If dusty winds are blowing from the west, he should close the windows on the western side. If dusty winds are blowing from the north, he should close the windows on the northern side. If dusty winds are blowing from the south, he should close the windows on the southern side. If the weather is cold, he should open the windows during the day and close them at night. If the weather is hot, he should close the windows during the day and open them at night.
pli-tv-kd18:12.11.199: If the yard is dirty, he should sweep it. If the gateway is dirty, he should sweep it. If the assembly hall is dirty, he should sweep it. If the water-boiling shed is dirty, he should sweep it. If the restroom is dirty, he should sweep it. If there’s no water for drinking, he should get some. If there’s no water for washing, he should get some.

pli-tv-kd18:12.11.201.1: “If the pupil becomes discontent with the spiritual life, the teacher should send him away or have him sent away, or he should give him a teaching.
pli-tv-kd18:12.11.202: If the pupil becomes anxious, the teacher should dispel it or have it dispelled, or he should give him a teaching.
pli-tv-kd18:12.11.203: If the pupil has wrong view, the teacher should make him give it up or have someone else do it, or he should give him a teaching.
pli-tv-kd18:12.11.204: If the pupil has committed a heavy offense and deserves probation,
pli-tv-kd18:12.11.205: the teacher should try to get the Sangha to give it to him.
pli-tv-kd18:12.11.206: If the pupil has committed a heavy offense and deserves to be sent back to the beginning,
pli-tv-kd18:12.11.207: the teacher should try to get the Sangha to do it.
pli-tv-kd18:12.11.208: If the pupil has committed a heavy offense and deserves the trial period,
pli-tv-kd18:12.11.209: the teacher should try to get the Sangha to give it to him.
pli-tv-kd18:12.11.210: If the pupil has committed a heavy offense and deserves rehabilitation,
pli-tv-kd18:12.11.211: the teacher should try to get the Sangha to give it to him.
pli-tv-kd18:12.11.212: If the Sangha wants to do a legal procedure against his pupil—whether a procedure of condemnation, demotion, banishment, reconciliation, or ejection—
pli-tv-kd18:12.11.213: the teacher should make an effort to stop it or to reduce the penalty.
pli-tv-kd18:12.11.214: But if the Sangha has already done a legal procedure against his pupil—whether a procedure of condemnation, demotion, banishment, reconciliation, or ejection—
pli-tv-kd18:12.11.215: the teacher should help the pupil conduct himself properly and suitably so as to deserve to be released, and try to get the Sangha to lift that procedure.
pli-tv-kd18:12.11.216: If the pupil’s robe needs washing, the teacher should show him how to do it,
pli-tv-kd18:12.11.217: or he should make an effort to get it done.
pli-tv-kd18:12.11.218: If the pupil needs a robe, the teacher should show him how to make one,
pli-tv-kd18:12.11.219: or he should make an effort to get one made.
pli-tv-kd18:12.11.220: If the pupil needs dye, the teacher should show him how to make it,
pli-tv-kd18:12.11.221: or he should make an effort to get it made.
pli-tv-kd18:12.11.222: If the pupil’s robe needs dyeing, the teacher should show him how to do it,
pli-tv-kd18:12.11.223: or he should make an effort to get it done.
pli-tv-kd18:12.11.224: When he’s dyeing the robe, he should carefully and repeatedly turn it over,
pli-tv-kd18:12.11.225: and shouldn’t go away while it’s still dripping.
pli-tv-kd18:12.11.226: If his pupil is sick, he should nurse him for as long as he lives or wait until he has recovered.
pli-tv-kd18:12.11.227: This is the proper conduct of a teacher toward his pupil.”
pli-tv-kd18:12.11.228: The eighth chapter on proper conduct is finished. In this chapter there are nineteen topics and fourteen kinds of proper conduct.
